source.title: 14-year lookback - CLT followed by PET
source.rationale: No official HMRC example showing 14-year cumulation where CLT affects PET's available NRB. This is one of the most complex areas of IHT and critical for accurate gift tax calculation.

testCase.description: CLT made 10 years before death, PET made 4 years before death - 14-year cumulation applies
testCase.scenario: Donor makes CLT of £200,000 in 2013, then PET of £400,000 in 2019, and dies in 2023. The CLT is outside the 7-year window for death (so no additional CLT tax), but it's within 7 years of the PET, so it reduces the NRB available for the PET calculation.

calculationNotes: 2023-06-01: Death (10.21 years after CLT, 3.73 years after PET)
For PETs, look back 7 years from the PET date for prior CLTs
This creates an effective 14-year window for CLT-PET interactions
Result: No additional CLT tax due at death
Step 2: Check if CLT affects PET
Result: CLT cumulates with PET, reducing NRB available
PET to death: 3.73 years (3-4 year band)
Taper relief: 20% (tax at 80% of full rate)
IMPORTANT: If the CLT had been made > 7 years before the PET:
- Full £325,000 NRB would be available for PET
- So the CLT timing cost £64,000 in extra tax!
This demonstrates why the 14-year rule is critical for planning
hmrcQuote: N/A - Synthetic case. Based on IHTA 1984 s.7 which requires cumulation of chargeable transfers in the 7 years before each transfer. For a PET failing on death, CLTs made up to 7 years before the PET must be considered, creating an effective 14-year window.
